title: 111_hr3550
content: The Act is titled the "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" defines "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older and specifies the securities laws it encompasses. Amendments are made to the Securities Act of 1933, Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Investment Company Act of 1940 to include this definition. The term 'senior' is defined as an individual aged 62 or older in the Securities Act of 1933, Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Investment Company Act of 1940. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF SECURITIES ACT OF 1933. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include enhanced civil penalties for violations directed towards seniors, allowing the Commission to impose fines of up to $50,000 per violation. Additionally, a special rule for seniors is added to address violations committed against elderly individuals. The Securities Act of 1933 now allows the Commission to impose fines of up to $50,000 per violation for offenses targeting seniors. SEC. 4. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF SECURITIES ACT OF 1934. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for violations directed towards seniors. Additionally, willful violations directed towards seniors may result in enhanced penalties. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now includes a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for violations targeting seniors. SEC. 5. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF INVESTMENT COMPANY ACT OF 1940. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Investment Company Act of 1940 include a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards or committed against a senior. The Investment Company Act of 1940 allows the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards or committed against a senior. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF INVESTMENT ADVISERS ACT OF 1940. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include enhanced penalties for willful violations directed towards seniors, allowing the Commission to impose civil penalties of up to $50,000 for each violation. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to allow the Commission to impose civil penalties of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards seniors. Directive to the United States Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for violations of securities laws against seniors. This includes applying specific guidelines to offenses involving senior victims, maintaining consistency with other directives, making necessary changes, and aligning with sentencing purposes. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for violations of securities laws against seniors, including aligning with sentencing purposes outlined in section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code.
